title: Advanced Context Engineering for Agents
author: YC Root Access

key_facts: Dex is the founder of Human Layer and participated in the YC fall 2024 batch.
The term 'context engineering' was introduced in a June 2022 talk titled '12actor Agents: Principles of Reliable LLM Applications'.
Sean Grove's talk on 'vibe coding' was one of the most viewed AI engineering talks this year.
A Stanford study analyzed data from 100,000 developers across enterprises and startups.
AI-generated code often leads to rework, especially in complex or legacy systems.
Dex worked with a top-tier AI coder who delivered 20,000-line Go PRs every few days.
The team adopted spec-first development due to inability to review large code changes.
After 8 weeks, the team transitioned to a workflow where they no longer read every line of code.
The team now ships production code using a structured three-phase process: research, plan, implement.
The team maintains context utilization under 40% during implementation phases.
The team uses open-source prompts for research, planning, and implementation.
A 300,000-line Rust codebase was fixed in one shot via a collaborative podcast effort.
A 35,000-line code change was shipped in 7 hours with a mix of human and AI work.
An intern shipped two PRs on the first day and ten on the eighth day.
The team no longer reviews raw code; instead, they focus on specifications and plans.
key_opinions: Vibe coding is fundamentally flawed because it treats prompt specs as disposable.
AI-generated code can be counterproductive in complex brownfield tasks.
Spec-first development is essential for maintaining team alignment in large codebases.
Context window quality directly determines agent output quality.
Intentional compaction is more effective than simple restarts when agents go off track.
Sub-agents are useful for reducing context burden during code exploration.
The best way to use coding agents is through repeated, structured prompting over time.
Code review is primarily about mental alignment, not just correctness.
Focusing on problem specification yields higher returns than focusing on code generation.
Team adoption of new workflows will be difficult but necessary for success.
AI coding agents may become commoditized, but workflow transformation remains hard.
Human review of research and plans is more efficient than reviewing full code changes.
The current workflow saves significant engineering time despite high token usage.
Current practices are sustainable without switching to maximum model plans.
Effective context engineering requires intentional design of prompts and feedback loops.
